filedesc.updatestmt:
The editors of the William Blake Archive http://www.iath.virginia/edu/blake are pleased to announce the publication of four new electronic editions of Blake's illuminated books. They are: The Ghost of Abel Copy A (The Library of Congress), On Homers Poetry [and] On Virgil Copies B (The Fitzwilliam Museum) and F (The Pierpont Morgan Library), Laocoön Copy B (collection of Robert N. Essick).
These three works are Blake's final illuminated books, their composition dateable between 1822 (The Ghost of Abel, On Homers Poetry [and] On Virgil) and c. 1826-27 (Laocoön). In the words of Sir Geoffrey Keynes, they offer Blake's "Last Testament" on subjects ranging from aesthetic theory to political economy, from forgiveness to apocalyptic judgment. A drama in miniature, The Ghost of Abel addresses "Lord Byron in the Wilderness" (Plate 1) and, more specifically, the issues of vengeance and forgiveness raised by Byron's Cain: A Mystery (1821). The broadsheet On Homers Poetry [and] On Virgil challenges these representative figures of classical learning, with special emphasis on concepts of unity as an artistic ideal, identity, and the destructive consequences of imperialism. There are five copies extant for each of these works, which, like most of Blake's illuminated books, were produced in relief etching; the Laocoön plate, which is an intaglio etching/engraving, is extant in two copies. Through a careful representation and restoration of the famous Hellenistic sculptural group, Blake attempts to return the Laocoön to its supposed Hebraic origins and its allegorical meanings, revealed by the terse yet intellectually expansive texts with which Blake surrounds the central image.
All of these editions have newly edited SGML-encoded texts and are all fully searchable for both text and images and supported by the unique Inote and ImageSizer applications described in our previous updates. We now have twenty-six copies of sixteen illuminated books in the Archive. Late this year and early in the next, we will add Milton Copy D and Jerusalem Copy E. We will also be adding at least six more copies of Songs of Innocence and of Experience, two copies of Songs of Innocence, five copies of The Marriage of Heaven and Hell, four copies of The Book of Urizen, and two copies each of America, a Prophecy and Europe, a Prophecy. In addition, by the end of 1998 we will provide a fully-searchable SGML edition of David V. Erdman's Complete Poetry and Prose of William Blake.
In the coming weeks we will also be opening a brand-new wing of the Archive, consisting of an extensive array of supporting materials: an updated and expanded Plan of the Archive, a statement of Editorial Principles and Methodology, a summary of the Archive's technical design and implementation, a list of Frequently Asked Questions, an in-depth illustrated Tour highlighting the Archive's features and some ways to use its resources, and more. Our hope is that these extensive documentary materials will prove valuable both to our own growing user community as well as to scholars interested in the theory and practice of electronic editing more generally. We will make a separate announcement when these materials are available on the site.
Finally, on our recently opened Contributing Collections page, we plan to begin adding color-coded and linked lists of each institution's entire Blake collection to indicate what is and is not in the Archive and what is forthcoming. In addition to providing a convenient index of the scope and contents of the Archive, these lists should also be useful to scholars in planning research trips.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Cloud outlines surround the title at the top of the plate (line 1). Two gowned adult figures, perhaps a male (on the left) and a female (right of the male) hover in the top left corner of the plate. The male, facing right, seems to have his arms raised horizontally; the hem of his garment forms a snake-like tail. The female, facing right, has her arms raised horizontally and holds, or reaches for, an infant or child. This tiny figure probably faces to the right, with legs spread and at least one arm raised horizontally. He or she may be fleeing the adult female. On the right side of the plate, several figures surround "Abel" in the title (line 1). Slight indications of a figure facing left appear to the right of, and probably lean against, the first diagonal of "A." A figure, facing left, walks on top of the "B." At least one arm is extended horizontally and seems to be reaching for a hovering child or infant, facing right (toward the walking adult) with at least one arm raised horizontally. A figure kneels or sits on top of the "E," facing right and with at least one arm extended at 45 degrees. A very small figure, perhaps an infant or putto, hovers between the "E" and "L." This figure faces right, with legs spread and perhaps one arm raised at 135 degrees. A figure, apparently facing forward, sits or squats on the foot of the "L" with the left arm raised vertically. He or she may be reaching toward the extended arm of the gowned and standing figure to the right. This figure faces left and has both arms raised horizontally. This group of two figures on and just following the "L" suggests the raising of Lazarus by Christ. A group of three or four figures hovers in the top right corner of the plate. These are, from left to right, slight indications (clearer in other impressions) of a standing figure facing left with most of his or her body covered by the next figure described here; a (nude and female?) figure facing forward; a (nude and male?) figure facing forward but twisting to the right with arms raised to the right at 135 degrees; and a gowned figure seen from behind. The second and third of these figures are close together; they may be Adam and Eve. Beneath "A Revelation" (line 2) in the subtitle, a lion pursues a fleeing and leaping stag; both face right. Between them are some vague forms that may be the trunks of trees. Under "Jehovah" (line 2), the last word in the subtitle, we see two running figures, the one on the right pursuing the fleeing figure to the left. These human figures, facing left and both apparently nude, are clearly a parallel to the lion and stag on the left side of the plate. The left figure, perhaps Cain, has his legs spread apart in a dramatic stride to the left. His left leg is bent at the knee and the right leg is extended backward. His left arm is bent upward; he clutches his lowered head (in despair?) with at least his left hand. The right leg of the pursuing figure, perhaps a vengeful God, is bent dramatically at the knee; the left leg is extended backward. His arms are raised horizontally, with the raised hands palms out. It has also been suggested that these two figures are Cain pursuing Abel to murder him; indeed, there may be an object of some sort (a knife?) in the left hand of the pursuing figure. Vines with thorns grows right of "Blake" (line 3); one extends to the left under "Seen by William Blake." Four birds fly above the first three words of line 6 of the text; two or three more appear after the first word ("Adam") of line 13 and another two after the word "Jehovah" in line 15. Slight marks above "Eve" (line 9), "Grave" (line 10), and between "her" and "Jehovah" (end of line 10) may also be birds in flight. A vine or plant with leaves appears in the right margin, right of lines 6-7 of the text. The first letter of "Scene," the first word in line 9 of the text, grows into vines at both ends. The vine extending from this letter toward the left margin of the plate bears two standing figures, apparently facing each other. The left-most figure has at least one arm raised horizontally. Below "of Abel" at the start of line 10 of the text is a comet (with tail) or a shooting star. Further to the right below the same line are flames. Under the same line of text and further to the right are two figures—probably the dead body of Abel (lying supine on the left) and Cain (fleeing on the right). Both appear to be nude. Abel's arms are extended horizontally; his right leg is bent at the knee and perhaps crossed over his extended left leg. Cain, who we see from the back, strides energetically to the right, with his right leg bent sharply at the knee and his left leg extended backward. He seems to be looking back at his brother. Both arms are raised horizontally; he may be holding a knife in one of his hands. A gowned figure hovers, body horizontal, below "Adam" at the start of line 13 of the text. The figure's head is on the left with at least one arm extended horizontally to the left. A group of three (gowned?) figures, arms raised horizontally, hovers under "Is this Death?," in line 14 of the text. We see a vine or branch with one (oak?) leaf and several fruit right of line 14. Beneath the last four letters of line 13 is a snake, with its coiling tail on the right and its crested head, mouth open with tongue extended, on the left. This may be Satan in his serpent form.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The lower half of the left margin of the plate features three vignettes. Left of lines 17-21 of the text are two nude figures, almost certainly Eve (seen from behind on the left) and Adam (facing forward), as the inscriptions above and below the vignette indicate. Both have their legs crossed and stand in a contrapposto posture. Between them is a tree—probably the Tree of Life or the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and Evil—with several branches bearing large fruit. Lower right in the vignette, a vine with thorns grows upward and turns to the right below line 19 of the text. The vignette left of lines 28-31 of the text shows a figure lying supine on the ground, with the upper body raised, facing right, and perhaps leaning against the tree trunk on the left. This is probably Eve, who hears the voice of the dead Abel. This voice (or ghost) is pictured as the hovering figure above, just below the word "Abel" (line 28) inscribed above the vignette. His body is horizontal, with his head on the left and at least one arm extended horizontally. Below him, and right of Eve's feet, is a plant or small tree with several branches. The final vignette, left of lines 37-40 of the text, again pictures a nude Adam (on the right?) and Eve standing with a tree between them. Its branches are now bear. Eve, facing forward, stands in a contrapposto posture with legs crossed at the ankles. Her left arm is raised horizontally and she may be touching the left arm (bent upwards) of Adam—or giving him a fruit from the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and Evil. He is seen from behind, but he twists to the left. His legs are slightly spread, as though he were striding to the right (away from Eve). The ground below the figures includes some vegetation.

component.illusobjdesc: In the vignette left of lines 17-21 of the text, we see a tree with a nude, standing male just to the right. This is very probably Eve, as the inscription below and to the left of the vignette indicates. We see her from behind, with her legs crossed at the ankles and standing in a contrapposto posture. She may be looking at Adam on the right. Her left hand may be holding a branch of the tree.
Between the two figures in the vignette left of lines 17-21 of the text is a tree—probably the Tree of Life or the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and Evil—with several branches bearing large fruit.
A vine with thorns grows from the right corner of the vignette left of lines 17-21 of the text. It extends upward and then bends to the right below line 19.

The vignette left of lines 28-31 of the text shows a figure lying supine on the ground, with the upper body raised, facing right, and perhaps leaning against the tree trunk on the left. This is probably Eve, who hears the voice of the dead Abel (pictured as the hovering figure above).

The vignette left of lines 28-31 of the text shows a figure, head on the left, hovering above the supine figure. This hovering figure is probably Abel (or his voice or ghost); his name is etched just above the figure. His body is horizontal, with at least one arm raised horizontally. Given the textual context, he may be speaking.
In the vignette left of lines 28-31 of the text, and just right of the left margin of the plate, is a tree trunk. Right of the supine figure is another tree or plant with several branches.

In the vignette left of lines 37-40 of the text, a nude Eve (whose name is inscribed below the vignette) stands left of the tree. She faces forward in a contrapposto posture with her legs crossed at the ankles. Her left arm is raised horizontally; she may be touching the left hand of Adam (to the right)—or giving him a fruit from the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and Evil.

In the vignette left of lines 37-40 of the text, a nude Adam (whose name is inscribed above the vignette) stands right of the tree. We see him from behind, but his upper body is twisted to the left. His left arm is bent upward and reaches toward the extended left hand of Eve, the figure on the left. His legs are slightly spread; he may be striding to the right, away from Eve.

In the vignette left of lines 37-40 of the text, a tree with leafless branches (and fruitless—in contrast to the vignette left of lines 17-21) stands between the two figures. The ground below includes some indeterminate vegetation.

texthead.l: A Revelation In the Visions of Jehovah
To LORD BYRON in the Wilderness

lg.l: What doest thou here Elijah?
Can a Poet doubt the Visions of Jehovah? Nature has no Outline:
but Imagination has, Nature has no Tune: but Imagination has!
Nature has no Supernatural & dissolves: Imagination is Eternity
Scene. A rocky Country. Eve fainted over the dead body
of Abel which lays near a Grave. Adam kneels by her Jehovah
stands above
Jehovah Adam!
Adam -I will not hear thee more thou Spiritual Voice
Is this Death?
Jehovah_Adam!
Adam ___It is in vain: I will not hear thee
Henceforth! Is this thy Promise that the Womans Seed
Should bruise the Serpents head: Is this the Serpent? Ah!
Seven times O Eve thou hast fainted over the Dead Ah! Ah!
Eve revives
EveIs this the Promise of Jehovah! O it is all a vain delusion
This Death & this Life & this Jehovah!
Jehovah Woman! lift thine eyes
A Voice is heard coming on
VoiceO Earth cover not thou my Blood! cover not thou my Blood
Enter the Ghost of Abel
EveThou Visionary Phantasm thou art not the real Abel.
AbelAmong the Elohim a Human Victim I wander I am their House
Prince of the Air & our dimensions compass Zenith & Nadir
Vain is thy Covenant O Jehovah I am the Accuser & Avenger
Of Blood O Earth Cover not thou the Blood of Abel
JehovahWhat Vengeance dost thou require
Abel -Life for Life! Life for Life!
Jehovah He who shall take Cains life must also Die O Abel
And who is he? Adam wilt thou. or Eve thou do this
AdamIt is all a Vain delusion of the all creative Imagination
Eve come away & let us not believe these vain delusions
Abel is dead & Cain slew him! We shall also Die a Death
And then! what then! be as poor Abel a Thought: or as
This! O what shall I call thee Form Divine: Father of Mercies
That appearest to my Spiritual Vision: Eve seest thou also.
Eve _I see him plainly with my Minds Eye, I see also Abel living:
Tho terribly afflicted as We also are. yet Jehovah sees him

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text, we see a barren (perhaps stony) landscape with dark clouds in the sky. A figure, probably the dead Abel, lies supine on the ground. We see only his head on the left and the right side of his torso because another figure is lying over him. Although muscular, and identified by some scholars as either Cain or Adam, this prone figure with long, slightly curly hair is more probably Eve grieving or fainting (see Plate 1, lines 5-6) over her dead son. Her left arm is extended horizontally and her legs are crossed at the ankles. She wears a skirt over her loins and thighs, perhaps made of an animal (sheep?) skin with prominent fur or wool. Above this pair is a male figure, apparently nude, hovering horizontally in the sky. As the inscription on his right leg indicates, this is "The Voice of Abels Blood" (lines 34-35). His mouth is open and he may be speaking; his face suggests a mixture of anger and despair. His arms are crossed over his chest and wrapped around his body. The index finger of his left hand points to the inscription on his body. He faces forward, legs together, with his head twisted to the left; his hair is slightly curly and seems to be blown to the left by a wind. Smoke billows up below and to the left of his feet, as though he were a vision or ghost emanating from Abel's funeral pyre.

component.illusobjdesc: The sky below the text is filled with dark clouds. Smoke billows up from the ground, lower left, and extends around the hovering figure. illustration.illusobjdesc: The left margin of the text is decorated with five vignettes. Left of lines 1-2 is a gowned figure, hunched over at the waist and apparently walking to the left. A flock of five birds surrounds the figure. She or he holds a large object in at least the left arm (reaching downward) and hand. The figure has been identified as Eve, although he might be Adam (the name inscribed just below the vignette). The object he or she carries has been described as a book, Abel's coffin, and the stone tablets of the decalogue. The vignette left of lines 6-10 shows two figures. On the far left, a figure sits on a bed or drapery- covered stool. He or she is twisted, with the upper body facing forward but the head and arms facing to the right. The left arm is raised horizontally, with the right arm bent and the forearm raised horizontally. Both hands may be pushing against the figure to the right. This seated figure has been identified as Eve or God ("Jehovah" is inscribed beneath the vignette [line 11]) being rejected by the figure to the right. The figure on the right, probably a nude male seen from behind, has his left (trailing) leg bent and extended backward. He has generally been identified as Abel (or his soul). His left arm is raised horizontally, with the left hand touching, perhaps pushing against, the head of the seated figure to the left. The running figure's right arm is bent upward over his head. We see a hovering, gowned figure, body horizontal, left of line 14. He or she faces left and has at least the left arm raised at 45 degrees. This might be the soul or ghost of Abel. A flock of eleven birds surrounds the human figure. The vignette left of lines 17-21 pictures two nude (male?) figures. The right-most figure in the group, seen from behind, hovers above the other with legs together and bent at the knees. His arms are bent upward, with hands raised palms up. He leans to the left and may be looking at the figure below. He is seated (on a mound of earth or stone?). He faces forward, but his head is twisted to the right. His arms and hands are in much the same position as his companion's. His legs are crossed at the ankles. These figures have been identified as God (seated) arguing or contending with Satan (see "Satan" and "Jehovah" inscribed immediately above and below this vignette [lines 16, 22]). The final vignette, left of lines 23-27, pictures two nude figures standing on either side of a tree with a large, thick trunk. A few branches extend from the top of the tree; one branch, descending on the right side of the vignette, bears fruit. This is almost certainly the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and Evil, with the spiral form encircling it representing the body of Satan in his serpent form. The figure on the left, legs together, is facing forward. This is probably Adam, perhaps with his arms drawn back behind his back. On the right, we see Eve from behind, perhaps with her legs crossed at the ankles. A vine appears to spring from Eve's lower legs; it extends horizontally above the first three words of line 27 of the text.

component.illusobjdesc: The vignette left of lines 1-2 of the text shows a gowned figure, hunched over at the waist and apparently walking to the left. She or he holds a large object in at least the left arm (reaching downward) and hand. The figure has been identified as Eve, although he might be Adam (the name inscribed just below the vignette). The object he or she carries has been described as a book, Abel's coffin, and the stone tablets of the decalogue.
A flock of five flying birds surrounds the figure in the vignette left of lines 1-2 of the text.

The vignette left of lines 6-10 of the text shows two figures. On the far left, a figure sits on a bed or drapery- covered stool. Her or she is twisted, with the upper body facing forward but the head and arms facing to the right. The left arm is raised horizontally, with the right arm bent and the forearm raised horizontally. Both hands may be pushing against the figure to the right. This seated figure has been identified as Eve or God ("Jehovah" is inscribed beneath the vignette [line 11]) being rejected by the figure to the right.

In the vignette left of lines 6-10 of the text, the figure on the right, probably a nude male seen from behind, has his left (trailing) leg bent and extended backward. He has generally been identified as Abel (or his soul). His left arm is raised horizontally, with the left hand touching, perhaps pushing against, the head of the seated figure to the left. The running figure's right arm is bent upward over his head.
We see a hovering, gowned figure, body horizontal, left of line 14 of the text. He or she faces left and has at least the left arm raised at 45 degrees. This might be the soul or ghost of Abel.
A flock of eleven birds surrounds the human figure.

The vignette left of lines 17-21 of the text pictures two nude (male?) figures. The right-most figure in the group, seen from behind, hovers above the other with legs together and bent at the knees. His arms are bent upward, with hands raised palms up. He leans to the left and may be looking at the figure below. He is seated (on a mound of earth or stone?). He faces forward but his head is twisted to the right. His arms and hands are in much the same position as his companion's. His legs are crossed at the ankles. These figures have been identified as God (seated) arguing or contending with Satan (see "Satan" and "Jehovah" inscribed immediately above and below this vignette [lines 16, 22]).

The vignette left of lines 23-27 of the text pictures two nude figures standing on either side of a tree with a large, thick trunk. A few branches extend from the top of the tree; one branch, descending on the right side of the vignette, bears fruit. This is almost certainly the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and Evil with Satan in his serpent form encircling the trunk.
In the vignette left of lines 23-27 of the text, the spiral form encircling the tree trunk is very probably Satan in his serpent form.
In the vignette left of lines 23-27 of the text, the nude figure standing left of the tree, facing forward, is probably Adam. His legs are together and he may have his arms drawn back behind him.
In the vignette left of lines 23-27 of the text, the nude figure standing right of the tree is probably Eve. We see her from behind; her legs are together and perhaps crossed at the ankles.
A vine extends from the lower legs of the right-most figure in the vignette. It reaches horizontally above the first three words of line 27 of the text.
